turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in 75-1704, Alexander against Fioto.
Mr. Urbanczyk, you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
This case is here on appeal by the Secretary of the Army from a judgment of the three-judge District Court in the Eastern District of New York.

The case generally concerns a provision of the Army and Air Force Vitalization and Retirement Equalization Act, a statute enacted in 1948 to establish retirement pay for non-regular military servicemen.
The provision at issue here, 10 U.S.C. 1331(c), precludes Appellees and others from becoming eligible for benefits or retirement pay under this Act.

The District Court held that that statutory eligibility bar as it applies to Appellees violates the Principle of Equal Protection that inheres in the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment, and the District Court has, in effect, enjoined the continued enforcement of that provision.
The pertinent facts of this case are simple and straightforward.
The Act was passed in 1948 after the war.
In the Act, Congress for the first time established a modest form of retirement pay for members of the Armed Forces Reserve and the National Guard.
I use the term "modest", because under the computation formula, the amount of retirement pay that an eligible reservist usually would receive is relatively modest and relatively small.
In this case, for example, the record shows that if he were eligible, appellee Fioto would receive annually $1100.

Now, to be eligible to receive retirement pay under this Act, the Statute provides generally that an individual must be at least 60 years old and have performed 20 years of eligible or qualifying service.
But those general-eligibility criteria are expressly made subject to the exception in Section 1331(c), which is the statutory provision under consideration in this case.
Section 1331(c) pertains to all individuals who are in the Reserves prior to August 16th, 1945.
That date marks the announcement by Japan that they would unconditionally surrender and the beginning of demobilization in World War II.

As originally enacted, the statute provided that individuals in the non-regular military service before that date were ineligible to receive retirement pay if they failed to perform active-duty service during either World War.
In 1958, the statute was amended to permit such individuals to receive retirement pay or to become eligible to receive retirement pay if they had subsequently served on active duty in the Korean War.
Appellee Fioto’s case, I think, illustrates the application of this statute.
Mr. Fioto was in the National Guard from 1933 to 1940.
The record does not explain the reason why his enlistment was discontinued at that time; but in any event, his enlistment was discontinued, and he did not serve on active duty in World War II.
In 1947, shortly after the war, Mr. Fioto rejoined and re-enlisted in the National Guard, and he thereafter served for 20 years until his mandatory retirement age in 1967.
Fioto did not serve on active duty during the Korean War.
Now, the Retirement Pay Act, as I mentioned earlier, was enacted in 1948, less than a year after Mr. Fioto re-enlisted in the Reserves in 1947.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: but the only reason he did not serve in the Korean War was because his unit was inactive.
Isn't that true?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is what the record -- the record shows that he did not serve on active duty in Korean War, because his ... that is what the Court found, because his unit was not activated, that is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So it was no fault of his.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: The reason for his not serving on active duty in the Korean War, the Court found, was through no fault of his own, that is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What is the significance of the dates September 8, 1940 on the one hand and January 1st, 1947 on the other ...

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is an interesting question, Your Honor.
I can give you the answer to second one.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: ... rather than December 7th, 1941 and August 1945.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Wasn’t that the date of mobilization of the National Guard?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is correct, Mr. Justice Blackmun.

On August 27th, 1940, Congress passed and the President signed a bill authorizing him to call up a National Guard in this hemisphere for a year; and also on September 16th, the Selective Service Act was passed.
So, about that time, the Government was beginning to mobilize in preparation for the war.
Now, the January 1st, 1947 date is an interesting one.
December 31, 1946 was the date that President Truman formally announced an end of hostilities in the World War. So even though we had --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He was little late in getting around to it, wasn't he?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: VE day and VJ Day, yes, that is correct, Mr. Justice. I think that history will show that he did that primarily to reduce excise and other luxury taxes; but in any event, that was the case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The triggering effect on other Legislation and Executive Orders.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is right.
In any event, that does mark the, I guess, the official historical end to World War II for this country.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Urbanczyk, I suppose you concede that had Mr. Fioto not served prior to World War II, he would be eligible.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is correct.
We have conceded that in this case, that is right, Mr. Justice Blackmun.
After his retirement, Fioto’s applications for retirement pay were denied predictably under Section 1331(c), and he then filed this lawsuit on behalf of himself and others similarly situated.
Now, in the Complaint in the District Court, and indeed until the brief on the merits in this Court, Appellees have implicitly conceded that they were barred from eligibility by Section 1331(c).
Their sole contention instead was that that statute was unconstitutional, and that has been the focus of this litigation.
Now, for the first time in their brief, they make the contention -- and it appears to be their principle contention now -- that the Section 1331(c) does not bar Appellees.
I can only take this to be an implicit acknowledgment of the weakness of their constitutional argument.

But before addressing that argument, I should make mention, then, of what we stated briefly in our brief, and that is that Section 13, there can be no doubt that Section 1331(c) bars individuals like Appellees from receiving retirement pay under this Act.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the person would be barred, even though he had 20 years of service quite apart from any service he may or may not have had during these critical days.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is correct, Mr. Justice Stewart.

The class is defined as individuals who have had now 20 years of service since 1945, but who also were in the non-military service at some point prior to 1945 and did not serve on active duty during the war.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So they are penalized for having been in the service prior to 1945.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: I hate to use the word "penalized", Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, made ineligible by the very fact that they were in the Reserve prior to 1945.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is right.

This class must be presumed to have known in 1948 -- that is when the statute was enacted -- that they would not be eligible or they could not become eligible to receive retirement pay, and this Appellee class nevertheless continued their enlistment.
As I was saying, the statute could not be written in any plainer terms.
The general-eligibility criteria of Section 1331 are made expressly subject to Subsection (c).

That provision says that no individual who was in the non-regular military service before August 16th, 1945, quote, “is eligible for retired pay under this chapter unless he performed active duty”, and then it goes on to specify the dates that correspond to the beginning and end of the World Wars and the Korean War.
There is only one reasonable construction of that statute, I think, and that is that persons described by it, including Appellees, are, “not eligible for retired pay under this chapter”.

Moreover, as we explained in our brief, Congress understood both at the time of the statute’s enactment and subsequently thereafter when it was reconsidering this statute, that that was the effect of Section 1331(c).

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How many people were affected, do you know?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: No, I am sorry.
One of the problems with the judgment in this case is that we would have to go through several million files in order to identify who it was that might be eligible for this retirement pay.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And if he had not mentioned this when he made his claim, he would have gotten it, I guess.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: If he had not mentioned what, Mr. Justice Marshall?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The earlier service.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: No, I think the application would then have called for the bringing forth of his records and the reviewing of his records.
I am not sure what his application looked like.
It is in the record now, and I forget whether he made mention of his prior service.
But in any event the record was found, and it was seen that he had served prior to 1945, and he was explicitly denied retirement benefits on the basis of that prior service.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Has there been an administrative determination that an applicant cannot simply waive any prior service, say, "I am relying only on my 20 years’ service after 1945 -- '47"?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: The waiver would not be permitted by the express terms of this statute.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, has that been decided?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Well, it has been decided, I would think, implicitly in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, in this case, except there was no effort to waive.
It was all brought out, "Here's my service".

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Well, Mr. Fioto, I think in his current brief, has indicated that he would be --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He declined to waive now, I am sure.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: -- that he would be unwilling to or that he would be willing to forego those seven years and just count on these 20; but the point is, in 1948 Congress made the determination that it was unwilling to offer this retirement-pay incentive to this individual.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does the amount of the pension depend upon the years of service over 20; i.e., my question is, if one has served 20 years, does he get the same pension as a person who served 29 years?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: No.

The computation formula is a little complex; but what it is basically is, you take the monthly pay that this person would have received as a reservist, you multiple it times 2.5% times the years of service that he performed.

Now, but the catch on that is, a reservist, a year of service may only count -- one year of serving may only count as 50 days for the purpose of computing the amount of retirement pay he would receive, so that typically it would take seven years of service to count for one year in terms of computing how much retirement pay a person would receive.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, if a person did waive his pre-1947 years of service, he would be waiving something.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is right, he would be receiving less retirement pay.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Less, less, less retirement pay.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is correct.

I think, though, that the crucial constitutional question, since I think there can be no doubt that the statute does pertain to Appellees and does bar them from receiving retirement pay, is whether the Section 1331(c) is rationally related to a valid legislative purpose.
As we have explained at length in our brief, the statute under consideration here is related to the two principle purposes of the Act.

The Act was designed first as a cost-effective method of enlisting and maintaining a peacetime reserve of individuals who would be willing to fight, if necessary, and who would be trained or have the experience to fight effectively; and, second, the Act was designed to reward the past service of those who had performed the functions for which a militia is maintained by serving on active duty in wartime.
I do not think I need to elaborate these general considerations beyond what is said in the brief.
In response, Appellees seem to suggest that the statute was intended to provide essentially an undifferentiated incentive to one and all to join the Reserves.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What would happen with another man who was in another National Guard that was activated in Korea, but did not go to Korea?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Well, if he was activated and put on active duty and therefore served his country --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And never went to Korea, he would be eligible?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Yes, that is correct.
He would be eligible under the statute.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And could it be that both of them would be in the same area?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: The point of the Korean statute or the Korean amendment was to permit individuals who for one reason or another had been unable to fight in the war in World War II, if they were called on active duties then to be able to become eligible to receive retirement pay.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, it all depends on the luck of the draw as to which one was activated.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Well, I think the general statute pertains to people --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, that is true.
There is no way around that.
He cannot change from one National Guard to the other, can he?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Well, I do not know that, Mr. Justice Marshall.
I do not know what he could do to have joined on active duty during the Korean War.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You do not know that? Well, do not you think it is material?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Well, no, I do not.
I think that the essential point here --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The whole point is that whether or not he is activated is absolutely beyond his control.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: No, but the essential point in the statute --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that true?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That may well be correct, Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that true?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That it was beyond his control as to whether or not he served on active duty in the Korean War?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: I am afraid I cannot answer the question yes or no.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Do you know whether there was any provision during that period of hostilities for volunteers to join the Army?
Was any statute prohibiting people from joining the Army?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: I am sure there was not, Mr. Justice...

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, he certainly had the power to join the Army, didn't he?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Wasn't that the answer to Justice Marshall?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Well, there is another answer, too, I think, although that is certainly one answer.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would that have affected his money?

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: He would have been qualified then.
His retirement money?

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: He would have been qualified then.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Well, if he had served on active duty in any capacity, I think he would then have been qualified to receive retirement pay or to become eligible for retirement pay.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If he had been enlisted at the last day of the Korean War, then okay.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Yes, I think that is right, if he had served on active duty; but the gist of this statute, I think, is directed at individuals who failed to serve on active duty during the two World Wars.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But was that not directed specifically to encourage men with combat experience, with active service experience at least, to go into the Reserves?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That was one of those essential purposes of the Act.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Wasn't that essentially the testimony of Colonel Maas that you refer to in your brief?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is correct, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Excuse me before we go on.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Yes, I am sorry.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The focus of that revitalization, as you put it, was to get not desk soldiers or just the ordinary National Guardsmen, but get the young men who had been in active service during the wartime to move into the Reserves so that they would have at least a partially combat-trained Reserve.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is correct, and that is, as you say --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And you rest on that as the basis for a different treatments of those who have had active-duty service.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Urbancyzk.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And what do you say is unreasonable and unconstitutional about that?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: We feel that the intent of Congress was, in order to get credit for those years, you must have served in the war; but they never intended to exclude people with 20 years of measurable service under the new point system.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, except ... must you not concede that the statutory language is very clear ...

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: We say that the --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: ... that a person is not eligible, it says, for retired pay under this chapter?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, we think as both the court below and the U.S. Attorney felt at that time that it was legislative oversight in the wording of this statute, that the intent --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would you answer my question, and then you can explain it?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: The plain meaning of the statute, we will agree, would disentitle our client to retired pay; however, we feel that a different construction should be given to that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That that is not what Congress meant to say.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: We feel that is not what Congress meant to say and that the Court can give a different interpretation to the statute, that you can read in the words that "shall not qualify for credit for those years before 1945" that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Instead of "shall not be eligible for retired pay under this chapter".

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Goldfarb, even under your view of the statute, say two men in 1945, each of whom has had 20 years in the Reserve, but say one of them like your client ... say your client needed the five prewar years to get his 20.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes, because we feel --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that is what you think that the statute means.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why do you think the Congress did that?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, the reason we feel that there was no measurable way of knowing how good that service was before 1948 when they passed the point system.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, how do they measure the benefits post-'48 any differently then just showed up for so many drills and wasn’t put on report and so forth?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: No, there was not a way to measure what the National Reservists were doing.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, wasn’t pre-World War II Reserve service compensated?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: It is my understanding that the compensation system for Reserve service was passed at around the same time in 1948 that this came into effect.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It was compensated, but there was no retirement, isn’t that it?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: No, my understanding is that along about ... we mention in our brief another statute that was passed around the same period of time that gave compensation for the drills that Reservists participated in, and before that it is my understanding that it was not compensated.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Let's go back.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes, that they were in the Reserves without pay.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Of any kind.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Without pay of any kind.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I am not talking about the Reserve, I am talking about the National Guard.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: I do not know whether the National Guard was paid or not at that time.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: As you read the District Court’s opinion, do you read it to adopt your first argument, i.e., that under the statute as properly construed your client is entitled to retirement pay, or do you read it as adopting your second argument, i.e., that the statute can only be construed as it is in written, but that such a statute is unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: I believe it is not completely clear.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It is not clear to me, either.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: But they do say that it would be unconstitutional if they adopted the Army’s construction, and therefore they put in the sentence -- and we have it in our brief, Page 16 at Footnote 8, "We" --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: "We need not and should not defer to the Army’s construction."

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that construction is at odds with Congress’s clear purposes and goals.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, they say earlier that it is unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They did not have to say both, did they?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, I guess they felt that the statutory construction would be enough; but I think they explained ... possibly, they are explaining their reason that if you do not reach the statutory construction, you would have to reach to a constitutional question.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: "Accordingly, we hold that as applied to Plaintiff, the statute violates the minimum requirements imposed by the Equal Protection Clause."

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: "As applied", as applied by the Army.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, as applied to the Plaintiff ...

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Right, but they do not say whether --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: ... and the other members of his class.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, they say it is unconstitutional to apply it.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: That way.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But then later, they say, "We do not construe the statute to disqualify him."

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: But they say the Government has, and the Government has applied it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, it is not your burden to testify to every sentence in the opinion.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I suppose if the Court had just stopped with saying the statute was unconstitutional as construed to cover your client to exclude him, then does it automatically follow that the Government would have to pay the retirement?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: If the statute does not bar, for either reason, our client, I think it automatically follows that the Government has to pay.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, it is an equal-protection argument; it is an equal-protection violation.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: I think in either case, if that proviso is either construed to include our client because he was only credit they were talking about or the proviso was stuck down as being unconstitutional and is no longer a bar, in either case retirement benefits would have be paid and because --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If the constitutional violation is that you are treating two classes differently that should have been treated the same, there is more than one way of curing the discrimination.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, I think the problem is there that the Court would only declare the proviso unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How do you know what Congress’s intention might be --

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Because I think we have --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- If they knew half their statute was unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, the thing is that we have the legislative history here, which shows the purpose of the entire statute, which was to confer this benefit on people with 20 measurable years.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what if you agreed?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: The problem is that the words of the statute do not carry out that purpose.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, how do you know they do not?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, no, what I am saying is that they are not discouraging everyone with no wartime service, but only one class of people.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I understand that, but how do you know if they say, "We are going to discourage as many as we can by this particular provision"?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, first of all, we feel that --

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: We feel that it would not have a -- that this proviso would not fit in with the purpose of the statute, which was to encourage --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, if you keep saying that, why you have bound to win.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, our feeling is --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that the purpose is not to give them pay; the purpose is not to give them retirement.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: But our feeling is that the way this statute works, it creates an impermissible classification, because there is no rational reason to discriminate between the man --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, you keep saying that; but I am just positing to you that let us just assume that it was perfectly clear in the statute that the purpose was to discourage people from staying in, and that they were doing it and they are going to discourage it by not providing for retirement pay.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: It would be an irrational purpose and against the purpose ... the purpose of this one subsection, then, would be working against the purpose of the whole statute, and we feel it would be still unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean, Congress could not have had more than one purpose in the same statute?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes, but I think when you have a purpose of a small subsection, which is on head-on collision with the purpose of the entire section, you have to look to the purpose of the entire section. Ad secondly, the problem here is that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, it was not unconstitutional -– you think it was unconstitutional to discourage people from staying in the Army?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: It was unconstitutional to make this kind of irrational classification between two groups of men and with no basis for having one that would stay in and one that would not stay in, the two groups of men being the two that came in 1947 and served their 20 years, and just because one had seven prior years --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know the Act.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, as I said at first, we do not feel that this was ... there is no legislative evidence that they were trying to discourage or penalize any group of people.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, they recently were trying to encourage, were they not, the combat active-duty members to stay in the Reserves?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, that was a very small part of the testimony among lots of other purposes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, as Justice White suggested, there would be myriad purposes they would have in mind; but certainly that testimony indicates that the military were very much interested in keeping these younger men with active duty in the Reserves.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: I think there appears to be a purpose, a benign purpose, to give a retirement benefit to those who had served on active wartime duty and to include that along with the rest of the Act.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would it had been a rational purpose, had it been expressed, but would it have been a rational purpose to say that a man who had some substantial prewar service and then some substantial 20 years after the war, but not be given any special favors as compared with the men who had those factors plus active duty?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: That would be the -– the finding of the courts below in his case was that he was not able to participate in the war.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, does this man fall in any one of those categories?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: This man, according to the findings of fact of the court below, was a victim of a car accident in approximately the time he dropped out of the Reserves and had not sufficiently recovered to be in Reserves at the time of the war.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: For five years after the accident.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Right, and in 1940 he was in a serious accident.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does the record support that?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: It was a finding of fact of the court below.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where did he find the evidence to make the finding of fact?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: If I recall, the questions on oral argument.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And showing no evidence, then, at all.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well then, the class, whatever his individual reasons were, that does not affect the class, does it?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Right, it does not affect the class.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The class might include people with reasons similar to this asserted reason or for no reason or for reasons of cowardice or for reasons of heroism or all sorts of different reasons.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: And I think our point which we feel is important on that is that there were people who also did not have prior wartime service who came in in '47 or '45 for the first -- after August 16, 1945 for the first time were not even required to serve in the Korean War and could get the benefit of the statute.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But they inferentially as a group would be younger men.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Not necessarily.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not necessarily, but they would…

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: No, many of them, in fact, were not, because they came in in relation to needing the job because they were Merchant Marines or because they had another civilian job which required them to be in the Reserves.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that is some of them.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: I mentioned that they put no age limit on it other than --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, certainly a 70-year-old man cannot go down and enter for the first time, can he?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: No. In order to -- he has a retired -- there is a mandatory retirement at 60, and in order to get your 20 years in, you would have to come in before you are 40.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, isn’t there some age limit for an original applicant?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: It is not my understanding that there is an age limit other than the mandatory retirement age at age 60, and you have to reenlist, I think, every 5 years; so Mr. Fioto’s last period of enlistment was between the ages of 55 and 60.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So at least you can say that you cannot originally apply if you are over 60, because you are eligible to retire mandatorily.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Perhaps I did not get straight your answer to Brother Stevens' question as to what you thought the purpose of Congress was in barring, as you seem to concede, are barred by the statute a man who had 15 years after and 5 years before without wartime service before.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: When the statute was created, they created the measurement of what is a good year of service.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, here are two people who both with 15 years after the war and 5 years before; one of them had wartime overseas service, and the other one did not.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: They decided that since there was no point system before '48, they would give people credit for the years before '48 if they had active wartime duty.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I know.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: That is because there was no way to measure the other service other than whether or not you were in active wartime duty.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, why did they say one gets retirement and one not?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: No, they said that we can measure years after '48.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I am not talking about Mr. Fioto.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, you are describing what the test is; but what is the rationale for distinguishing between those two men?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: I think it was a purpose to say, we are going to give them a benefit of the doubt, that we are going to give a benign --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What doubt?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: That the service before '48 was definitely good enough to qualify.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It is a merits thing, you think.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: It could be, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You served and the other fellow did not, and therefore we are going to give you retirement.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: I do not think that that is evident from the legislative history.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Goldfarb, what is your support for your suggestion that there was an inability on the part of the military establishment to evaluate the quality of the service performed before 1948?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: The Congress, in passing the Legislation in 1948 in the Senate hearings, said they wanted to create a uniform system among all the branches of the service, and they created the point system and they said that they did not want to leave it up to the branches of the service where the Navy would make one system and the Army make another system and they would evaluate.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, does the record tell us whether records were available so that that kind of computation could have made with respect to pre-1948 service?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: The Congressional hearings are blind to that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They wanted a new point system to be uniform as between the Army and the Navy.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Right, all the branches of service then, and they felt that this was significant, that they would not be --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But they are counting the pre-1948 service for those who did serve during World War II, are they not?

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: They gave that as a benefit sort of; so as not to penalize them in a sense, they gave that to them as an additional benefit, because they said we cannot measure those years, we will take this as the criteria.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, they also gave it to people who might not have been in the war, but first did the Reserve service in '46 and '47.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes, because I think the only --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Apparently, there were records available for those years.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: There were no records, I think they gave that because there was no other system.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But they were able to -– I mean, they did not need a point system to decide those years qualified is what I am saying.

turn.speaker: david_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. David Goldfarb
turn.text: No, they just gave that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Just a minute or two, if I may, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Go ahead.

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: I agree with you, Mr. Justice Stewart, that the District Court’s opinion is somewhat vague on its intent; but I think the most reasonable construction is that the District Court held this statute unconstitutional as applied to Appellees.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Urbanczyk, will you explain to me how they computed the year in 1946 and '47?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: Well, that is my point.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, does that mean that attending one drill in 1947 would give a man a full year’s credit?

turn.speaker: stephen_l_urbanczyk
turn.label: Mr. Stephen L. Urbanczyk
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
